doc.title: TipDate

description.text: Analysis of trees with dated tips

doc.reference: Andrew Rambaut, 2000. Estimating the rate of molecular evolution: Incorporating non-contemporaneous sequences into maximum likelihood phylogenies. Bioinformatics.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: TipDate requires a sequence alignment together with a description of the quartets and dates to be used. The idea is that the user may supply an alignment of a large number of species and then define multiple quartets to be constructed from them.

Note that the sequences names have a date at the end (in this case in years). TipDate looks for any number at the end of the names and assumes these are dates. They can be decimal (i.e. 98.2) is 98 and 1/5 (if you want months specify the whole date in months). The units are arbitrary because the rates and dates estimated by the program will be specified in the same units the program doesn't need to know what they are.
xhtml:div.div:
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
6 24 StrainA98 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGAAGCCCCTA StrainB96 CAGCTCTGTCTCCTGCAGCCCCTA StrainC97 CGGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTG StrainD97 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTG StrainE64 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCTTA StrainF77 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTA 1 (((StrainA98:1,StrainB96:1):2,(StrainC97:1,StrainD97:1):2):3,(StrainE64:2,StrainF77:2):4);

div.pre: 6 24 StrainA98 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGAAGCCCCTA StrainB96 CAGCTCTGTCTCCTGCAGCCCCTA StrainC97 CGGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTG StrainD97 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTG StrainE64 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCTTA StrainF77 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTA 1 (((StrainA98:1,StrainB96:1):2,(StrainC97:1,StrainD97:1):2):3,(StrainE64:2,StrainF77:2):4);

xhtml:div.label:
MODEL (-m)?
F84 HKY REV (markov general reversable model)
Model This option sets the model of nucleotide substitution with a choice of either F84, HKY (also known as HKY85) or REV (markov general reversable model). The first two models are quite similar but not identical. They both require a transition transversion ratio and relative base frequencies as parameters. Other models such as K2P, F81 and JC69 are special cases of HKY and can be obtained by setting the nucleotide frequencies equal (for K2P) or the transition transversion ratio to 1.0 (for F81) or both (for JC69).

Molecular clock model (-k)?
Yes No
This option specifies the Molecular Clock model (Single Rate, SR model). This model is the equivalent of the DNAMLK program in PHYLIP or specifying the molecular clock option in PAUP*. The default (i.e., not specifying k) gives the Non-Clock model (Different Rate, DR model).

Variable Rate Tip Date Model (+w)?
off Maximum likelihood parameter (+w) Maximum likelihood parameter: only positive (+w+) Maximum likelihood parameter: only negative (+w-) User value for variable Rate (-w)
This option specifies the Variable Rate Dated Tip (VRDT) model. This model assumes that the rate of substitution changes linearly as we go back through time. The rate of change of rate is given as a proportion of the rate of substitution at the present. This rate can be positive or negative but not all data sets will have the power to estimate this parameter.
Using this option will estimate the rate of evolution as a maximum likelihood parameter. You can also constrain the estimation of this parameter to be only positive or only negative

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Variable Rate Tip Date Model with user value (-w)?
Where value is an real number that gives the rate of change of rate as proportion of rate at present per unit time.

Estimate confidence intervals ( require +w option) (-iw)?
Yes No
Estimate confidence intervals for the rate of change of rate parameter in the Variable Rate Dated Tip model (requires +w option).

Tip Date Model with estimation of the rate of evolution (+s)?
Yes No
This option specifies the Single Rate Date Tips (SRDT) model. The default value is the Non-Clock model. The input tree and sequences must have names that end with dates. Using this option will estimate the rate of evolution as a maximum likelihood parameter.

Estimate confidence intervals for the absolute rate of substitution (-is)?
Yes No
This option specifies which parameters should have confidence intervals estimated. The default is not to estimate confidence intervals. These options can be used in combination.
Estimate confidence intervals for date of root of tree (-id) Yes No

Limit to use estimating confidence intervals (-l)?
This option specifies the value to use to obtain the confidence intervals around the estimate of rate of molecular evolution (and corresponding date of root of the tree).
Where value is a real number >= 0 that specifies the log likelihood ratio that gives the confidence interval. The default is 1.92 which corresponds to half c2 with 1 degree of freedom. A value of 0 will disable the calculation of confidence intervals.

Tip date Model without estimation of the rate of evolution: user value (-s)?
Where the value is an real number that gives the rate of molecular evolution in substitutions per site per unit time (whatever the units of time that are represented by the input tip dates).
Variable Rate Tip Date Model This option specifies the Variable Rate Dated Tip (VRDT) model. This model assumes that the rate of substitution changes linearly as we go back through time. The rate of change of rate is given as a proportion of the rate of substitution at the present. This rate can be positive or negative but not all data sets will have the power to estimate this parameter. This model must be used in conjunction with the +s or -s options, above.

Estimate root tree (+r)?
Yes No
Alternatively TipDate can find the maximum likelihood position of the root. This tries all possible positions (2n-3) so increases the duration of analysis.

Specify rooting of tree To perform the molecular clock and tip date models (-r)?
The input tree must be rooted. This option is used to specify an outgroup sequence to root the tree with (sorry this is not very sophisticated: if you need to use more than one outgroup, root the tree before hand).
Where value is an integer number which refers to the sequence that will be used to root the tree (starting at 1).
CODON CATEGORIES = 112, 123, 120, etc. [default: homogeneity] (-p)

CODON-specific Rate Heterogeneity: #1 #2 #3 separated by commas (-c)?
Using this option the user may specify the relative rates for each codon position. This allows codon-specific rate heterogeneity to be modelled. The default is no site-specific rate heterogeneity.
Estimate seperate models for each site category (-e) Yes No

Discrete Gamma Rate Heterogeneity (2 to 32) (-g)?
Using this option the user may specify the number of categories for the discrete gamma rate heterogeneity model. Enter an integer between 2 and 32 that specifies the number of categories to use with the discrete gamma rate heterogeneity model.

Gamma Rate Heterogeneity (-a)?
Using this option the user may specify a shape for the gamma rate heterogeneity called alpha. The default is no site-specific rate heterogeneity. Where value is a real number >0 that specifies the shape of the gamma distribution to use with gamma rate heterogeneity.
Number of Datasets (-n)
User branch-lengths [default = estimate] (-ul) Yes No
Equal frequencies of nucleotide (-f=) Yes No

Relative nucleotide frequencies: #A #C #G #T separated by commas (-f)?
This option is used to specify the relative frequencies of the four nucleotides. By default, TipDate will estimate them empirically from the data. If the given values don't sum to 1.0 then they will be scaled so that they do.
Value is four decimal numbers for the frequencies of A, C, G and T respectively, separated by commas.

Transition/transversion ratio for F84/HKY model (-t)?
This option allows the user to set a value for the transition transversion ratio (TS/TV). This is only valid when either the HKY or F84 model has been selected. Value is a decimal number greater than zero.

Rate matrix values for REV model: 6 values separated by commas (-t)?
Where value are size decimal numbers for the instantaneous rates of change from A to C, A to G, A to T, C to G, C to T and G to T respectively, separated by commas. The matrix is symmetrical so the reverse changes occur at the same instantaneous rate as forward changes (e.g. C to A equals A to C) and therefore only six values need be set. These values will be scaled such that the last value (G to T) is 1.0 and the others are set relative to this.
Print final branch lengths (-vb) Yes No
Write likelihoods for each Site (-vs) Yes No
Don't Write trees (-vw) Yes No
Show indication of progress (-vp) Yes No

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: TipDate requires a sequence alignment together with a description of the quartets and dates to be used. The idea is that the user may supply an alignment of a large number of species and then define multiple quartets to be constructed from them.

Note that the sequences names have a date at the end (in this case in years). TipDate looks for any number at the end of the names and assumes these are dates. They can be decimal (i.e. 98.2) is 98 and 1/5 (if you want months specify the whole date in months). The units are arbitrary because the rates and dates estimated by the program will be specified in the same units the program doesn't need to know what they are.

Model This option sets the model of nucleotide substitution with a choice of either F84, HKY (also known as HKY85) or REV (markov general reversable model). The first two models are quite similar but not identical. They both require a transition transversion ratio and relative base frequencies as parameters. Other models such as K2P, F81 and JC69 are special cases of HKY and can be obtained by setting the nucleotide frequencies equal (for K2P) or the transition transversion ratio to 1.0 (for F81) or both (for JC69).

This option specifies the Molecular Clock model (Single Rate, SR model). This model is the equivalent of the DNAMLK program in PHYLIP or specifying the molecular clock option in PAUP*. The default (i.e., not specifying k) gives the Non-Clock model (Different Rate, DR model).

This option specifies the Variable Rate Dated Tip (VRDT) model. This model assumes that the rate of substitution changes linearly as we go back through time. The rate of change of rate is given as a proportion of the rate of substitution at the present. This rate can be positive or negative but not all data sets will have the power to estimate this parameter.
Using this option will estimate the rate of evolution as a maximum likelihood parameter. You can also constrain the estimation of this parameter to be only positive or only negative

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Where value is an real number that gives the rate of change of rate as proportion of rate at present per unit time.
Estimate confidence intervals for the rate of change of rate parameter in the Variable Rate Dated Tip model (requires +w option).

This option specifies the Single Rate Date Tips (SRDT) model. The default value is the Non-Clock model. The input tree and sequences must have names that end with dates. Using this option will estimate the rate of evolution as a maximum likelihood parameter.
This option specifies which parameters should have confidence intervals estimated. The default is not to estimate confidence intervals. These options can be used in combination.
This option specifies the value to use to obtain the confidence intervals around the estimate of rate of molecular evolution (and corresponding date of root of the tree).

Where value is a real number >= 0 that specifies the log likelihood ratio that gives the confidence interval. The default is 1.92 which corresponds to half c2 with 1 degree of freedom. A value of 0 will disable the calculation of confidence intervals.
Where the value is an real number that gives the rate of molecular evolution in substitutions per site per unit time (whatever the units of time that are represented by the input tip dates).

Variable Rate Tip Date Model This option specifies the Variable Rate Dated Tip (VRDT) model. This model assumes that the rate of substitution changes linearly as we go back through time. The rate of change of rate is given as a proportion of the rate of substitution at the present. This rate can be positive or negative but not all data sets will have the power to estimate this parameter. This model must be used in conjunction with the +s or -s options, above.
Alternatively TipDate can find the maximum likelihood position of the root. This tries all possible positions (2n-3) so increases the duration of analysis.

The input tree must be rooted. This option is used to specify an outgroup sequence to root the tree with (sorry this is not very sophisticated: if you need to use more than one outgroup, root the tree before hand).
Where value is an integer number which refers to the sequence that will be used to root the tree (starting at 1).
Using this option the user may specify the relative rates for each codon position. This allows codon-specific rate heterogeneity to be modelled. The default is no site-specific rate heterogeneity.

Using this option the user may specify the number of categories for the discrete gamma rate heterogeneity model. Enter an integer between 2 and 32 that specifies the number of categories to use with the discrete gamma rate heterogeneity model.

Using this option the user may specify a shape for the gamma rate heterogeneity called alpha. The default is no site-specific rate heterogeneity. Where value is a real number >0 that specifies the shape of the gamma distribution to use with gamma rate heterogeneity.

This option is used to specify the relative frequencies of the four nucleotides. By default, TipDate will estimate them empirically from the data. If the given values don't sum to 1.0 then they will be scaled so that they do.
Value is four decimal numbers for the frequencies of A, C, G and T respectively, separated by commas.

This option allows the user to set a value for the transition transversion ratio (TS/TV). This is only valid when either the HKY or F84 model has been selected. Value is a decimal number greater than zero.

Where value are size decimal numbers for the instantaneous rates of change from A to C, A to G, A to T, C to G, C to T and G to T respectively, separated by commas. The matrix is symmetrical so the reverse changes occur at the same instantaneous rate as forward changes (e.g. C to A equals A to C) and therefore only six values need be set. These values will be scaled such that the last value (G to T) is 1.0 and the others are set relative to this.

parameter.name: alignment

comment.text: TipDate requires a sequence alignment together with a description of the quartets and dates to be used. The idea is that the user may supply an alignment of a large number of species and then define multiple quartets to be constructed from them.

Note that the sequences names have a date at the end (in this case in years). TipDate looks for any number at the end of the names and assumes these are dates. They can be decimal (i.e. 98.2) is 98 and 1/5 (if you want months specify the whole date in months). The units are arbitrary because the rates and dates estimated by the program will be specified in the same units the program doesn't need to know what they are.

parameter.example: 6 24 StrainA98 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGAAGCCCCTA StrainB96 CAGCTCTGTCTCCTGCAGCCCCTA StrainC97 CGGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTG StrainD97 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTG StrainE64 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCTTA StrainF77 CAGCTCTGCCTCCTGCAGCCCCTA 1 (((StrainA98:1,StrainB96:1):2,(StrainC97:1,StrainD97:1):2):3,(StrainE64:2,StrainF77:2):4);

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: TipDate requires a sequence alignment together with a description of the quartets and dates to be used. The idea is that the user may supply an alignment of a large number of species and then define multiple quartets to be constructed from them.

Note that the sequences names have a date at the end (in this case in years). TipDate looks for any number at the end of the names and assumes these are dates. They can be decimal (i.e. 98.2) is 98 and 1/5 (if you want months specify the whole date in months). The units are arbitrary because the rates and dates estimated by the program will be specified in the same units the program doesn't need to know what they are.

format.code: ( "" , " -m" + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Model This option sets the model of nucleotide substitution with a choice of either F84, HKY (also known as HKY85) or REV (markov general reversable model). The first two models are quite similar but not identical. They both require a transition transversion ratio and relative base frequencies as parameters. Other models such as K2P, F81 and JC69 are special cases of HKY and can be obtained by setting the nucleotide frequencies equal (for K2P) or the transition transversion ratio to 1.0 (for F81) or both (for JC69).

message.text: Rates are specified by value, which are three decimal numbers, separated by commas.

parameter.name: freq_bases
parameter.prompt: Relative nucleotide frequencies: #A #C #G #T separated by commas (-f)

message.text: You must enter four decimal numbers separated by commas

comment.text: This option is used to specify the relative frequencies of the four nucleotides. By default, TipDate will estimate them empirically from the data. If the given values don't sum to 1.0 then they will be scaled so that they do.
Value is four decimal numbers for the frequencies of A, C, G and T respectively, separated by commas.

interface.label:
Relative nucleotide frequencies: #A #C #G #T separated by commas (-f)?
This option is used to specify the relative frequencies of the four nucleotides. By default, TipDate will estimate them empirically from the data. If the given values don't sum to 1.0 then they will be scaled so that they do.
Value is four decimal numbers for the frequencies of A, C, G and T respectively, separated by commas.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option is used to specify the relative frequencies of the four nucleotides. By default, TipDate will estimate them empirically from the data. If the given values don't sum to 1.0 then they will be scaled so that they do.
Value is four decimal numbers for the frequencies of A, C, G and T respectively, separated by commas.

format.code: ( "" , " -t" + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

message.text: Value is a decimal number greater than or equal to zero

comment.text: This option allows the user to set a value for the transition transversion ratio (TS/TV). This is only valid when either the HKY or F84 model has been selected. Value is a decimal number greater than zero.

interface.label:
Transition/transversion ratio for F84/HKY model (-t)?
This option allows the user to set a value for the transition transversion ratio (TS/TV). This is only valid when either the HKY or F84 model has been selected. Value is a decimal number greater than zero.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option allows the user to set a value for the transition transversion ratio (TS/TV). This is only valid when either the HKY or F84 model has been selected. Value is a decimal number greater than zero.

parameter.name: rate_matrix
parameter.prompt: Rate matrix values for REV model: 6 values separated by commas (-t)

message.text: Value are size decimal numbers separated by commas

comment.text: Where value are size decimal numbers for the instantaneous rates of change from A to C, A to G, A to T, C to G, C to T and G to T respectively, separated by commas. The matrix is symmetrical so the reverse changes occur at the same instantaneous rate as forward changes (e.g. C to A equals A to C) and therefore only six values need be set. These values will be scaled such that the last value (G to T) is 1.0 and the others are set relative to this.

interface.label:
Rate matrix values for REV model: 6 values separated by commas (-t)?
Where value are size decimal numbers for the instantaneous rates of change from A to C, A to G, A to T, C to G, C to T and G to T respectively, separated by commas. The matrix is symmetrical so the reverse changes occur at the same instantaneous rate as forward changes (e.g. C to A equals A to C) and therefore only six values need be set. These values will be scaled such that the last value (G to T) is 1.0 and the others are set relative to this.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Where value are size decimal numbers for the instantaneous rates of change from A to C, A to G, A to T, C to G, C to T and G to T respectively, separated by commas. The matrix is symmetrical so the reverse changes occur at the same instantaneous rate as forward changes (e.g. C to A equals A to C) and therefore only six values need be set. These values will be scaled such that the last value (G to T) is 1.0 and the others are set relative to this.
